review.title: Challenges in Providing Automatic Affective Feedback in Instant Messaging Applications
review.abstract: Instant messaging is one of the major channels of computer mediated communication. However, humans are known to be very limited in understanding others' emotions via text-based communication. Aiming on introducing emotion sensing technologies to instant messaging, we developed EmotionPush, a system that automatically detects the emotions of the messages end-users received on Facebook Messenger and provides colored cues on their smartphones accordingly. We conducted a deployment study with 20 participants during a time span of two weeks. In this paper, we revealed five challenges, along with examples, that we observed in our study based on both user's feedback and chat logs, including (i)the continuum of emotions, (ii)multi-user conversations, (iii)different dynamics between different users, (iv)misclassification of emotions and (v)unconventional content. We believe this discussion will benefit the future exploration of affective computing for instant messaging, and also shed light on research of conversational emotion sensing.

sections.heading: Introduction
sections.text: This year, it is only a matter of time before an agreement is reached.

sections.heading: EmotionPush System
sections.text: The task of predicting the emotion of a given text can be considered a document (sentence) classification problem when specifying the emotion categories. To ensure that the viable system performs well, we have introduced the powerful classification module LibSVM (Fan et al. 2008), a tool for supervised learning from support vector machines, and the widely recognized, well-functioning feature Word Embedding to train classification. Word embedding, generated from neural language models, has proven to be a successful feature for classification problems (Bengio et al. 2006; Huang et al. 2012; Mikolov et al. 2013a; Mikolov et al. 2013b). We have adopted pre-trained 300-dimensional word vectors trained under Google News2 and presented each sentence or document as a vector by presenting all the word vectors in the sentence or vector in the documentation.

sections.heading: Use Case of EmotionPush
sections.text: The goal of EmotionPush is to enable end users to better understand the emotions of their interlocutors. ● The most obvious use case we can think of is prioritizing messages according to the emotions they convey. ● Participants confirmed this use case by pointing out that EmotionPush can help them read their messages quickly and manage multiple messages at the same time. However, other use cases are not clear before users want to keep their emotions stable. In the usage study, participants identified some interesting use cases. We list these use cases as follows, along with quotes from participants. • Emotion Management Participants will be able to decide whether they want to receive some information to keep their emotions stable.

sections.heading: Different Users
sections.text: One risk of classifying emotions solely on the basis of texts is the neglect of the context that is known to have strong correlations with the user's behavior (Baym et al. 2007; Gilbert Wang and Karahalios 2009).

sections.heading: Conclusion & Future Work
sections.text: In this paper, we describe challenges in using an emotion recognition system, EmotionPush, for instant messaging applications. These challenges include the continuum of emotions, multi-user conversations, different dynamics between different users, misclassification and unconventional content. These challenges are not only about automatic affective feedback through the use of word processing technologies, but also about shaping a user experience in the face of interconnected factors such as humanity and languages. Through these discussions, we expect to gain insights into the use of affective data processing applications and motivate researchers to develop tomorrow's solutions. In the future, with the benefit of the developed EmotionPush, we plan to develop a mechanism that encourages users to contribute their content and feedback their emotions in order to drive this technology forward where it is most needed.
